body:
r? @brson

(rust_highfive has picked a reviewer for you, use r? to override)
Oh, and I haven't check what the documentation looks like. I expect that either (a) the inherent impl won't show up, (b) rustdoc will ICE or (c) the inherent impl will magically appear in libunicode.

re: docs. The `char` primitive appears in libunicode but it only shows the `impl char` methods. There is another `char` primitive in libstd, that one shows the `impl char` methods and other methods provided by traits.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23107) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
This...is remarkably simple. I'm in favor.

@japaric Sorry for not leaving a comment earlier -- I thought I had.

I'm delighted to see this! It will definitely help remove a few warts in the final days of stabilization. I talked with @alexcrichton about it at lunch today and he's also on board, so since @nikomatsakis approves I'd say let's roll this out across the full set of primitive types (including numerics). Thanks!

One part I'll also point out is that in the past when I dabbled with inherent methods on primitives I had to add special code to rustdoc to get things to work out. That may no longer be necessary, but could you give the primitive pages a quick glance to make sure all the methods are listed?

OK, this is _mostly_ done. There is a summary of the changes at the top, along with a preview of the docs (I haven't look at them closely yet). This branch passes `check-stage1` as it is but needs a rebase.

There is one caveat: Because `libcollections` now contains lang items, is not easy to run its unit tests with `rustc --test` because it results in conflicting lang items - this is a known issue. I discussed this with @alexcrichton, and we decided that easiest path forward was to split the unit tests into its own crate (a la core and coretest). However, after the split some unit tests no longer compile because they require access to the private fields of some structs. For now I've commented out these tests, but these tests need to be re-enabled before landing this.

How to deal with these tests? I see two alternatives right now: (a) we rewrite the tests to not access private fields, not sure if this is possible for all the tests, or (b) we move these tests back to libcollections, making this work can be tricky due to the original problem of conflicting lang items.

I'll take a look at the second option tonight.

cc @Gankro Do you think it would be possible to modify the commented out tests [1] to not access private fields while retaining the intention of the tests?

[1] See the "extract libcollections tests into libcollectionstest" commit, the tests are marked with "FIXME(japaric) privacy".

> we rewrite the tests to not access private fields, not sure if this is possible for all the tests

I would favor this wherever possible, although it probably depends on the test.

> we move these tests back to libcollections, making this work can be tricky due to the original problem of conflicting lang items

For a particular test it may not be too hard to get it to work, even with lang items. But it also depends on the test :)

Oof, migrating some of these tests would be really nasty. One option is to expose privates in `doc(hidden)` methods. The maintenance burden would be minimal, and anyone who uses them would be _super_ at fault.

For specific tests:

The Vec::permutations one I'd probably just toss the offending check as "whatever" (I'd also toss the permutations _api_ myself but that's just me).

LinkedList's integrity check could be made a doc(hidden) test, although honestly I don't think it's particularly _necessary_ to perform the check at all. LinkedList is my nemesis but it's not exactly mind-blowing complexity. Also you can emulate the checks by just providing a slice of the expected values and iterating forwards and backwards.

VecDeque is probably the toughest case. We totally abuse access to the internals for two things: minimum-cost bench resets, and enumerating every possible internal state of the Deque. In _theory_ you could do a whole mess of pushy-pops to slide the head of the list to exactly the right position, but that would perhaps be a bit fragile on top of being slower and more tedious. The check that `head < tail` is _mostly_ gratuitous, although I think it was added in response to an actual impl bug.

I don't see why enum_set is commented out; it looks like everything there is using the public API?

> One option is to expose privates in doc(hidden) methods.

I'm generally opposed to this idea, `#[doc(hidden)]` public API is still public API no matter how many underscores you add. I understand this is a necessary workaround for things like macros, but I'd like to avoid it in this case.

> I don't see why enum_set is commented out; it looks like everything there is using the public API?

My bad, I was importing `std::collections::EnumSet`, but just realized that I want `collections::EnumSet` because there is no std re-export in this case.

> Oof, migrating some of these tests would be really nasty.

Ok, I'll try to move these tests back to libcollections then.

Thanks for the input @Gankro!
I've re-enabled the tests after moving them back to libcollections (see two last commits). I'll double check the docs and rebase after that. But the review process can already start ;-).

Woot!

Does rustdoc handle these impls in some non-terrible way?
Sweet. Looks good to me, but someone else should take a look at the rustc changes.

@sfackler Thanks for taking a look!

This has been carefully rebased over the char stabilization PR, now all the `impl char` methods have documentation. The preview docs will get updated in half an hour or so. This should be ready to go, who wants to r?
I can r?
r? @nikomatsakis

I'm starting to somewhat have second thoughts about this from a compiler implementation perspective. From an API standpoint I think this change is fine largely because it doesn't really change much. Overall, however, this seems like it's all a bit of a hack. 

We're basically bending the language to our whim to enable this sort of functionality because we control the compiler, but from the perspective of some other hypothetical compiler implementor this becomes quite a pain. We're adding all these special cases for these very implementation-specific set of `impl` blocks for each primitive. Put another way, we've found the language inadequate for our desires so we're getting around that with some slight of hand that doesn't come up too much but likely will at some point.

I think the biggest pain points for me when reading this are:
- Such a huge number of lang items were added.
- Multiple inherent implementations on primitives is allowed

The lang item problem can probably be considered an implementation detail of the compiler, but allowing multiple inherent implementations makes me feel like something has gone awry somewhere. We don't have the luxury of always being able to bend the language so API design is a little easier, and I felt that the previous trait-per-primitive-in-the-prelude solution was quite adequate: it worked out well in terms of documentation, functionality, extensibility, and it was also consistent with the rest of the language.

@alexcrichton [my version of this plan](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/16293#issuecomment-71155548) was to define all the _named_ primitive types in libcore using, e.g. `#[lang="char"] enum char {}`. Does that seem like less of a hack to you?

> Multiple inherent implementations on primitives is allowed

Just to clarify, only a single inherent implementation, the one marked with the lang item, is permitted per primitive. Since each lang item is unique you can't have e.g. one inherent implementation per crate. Other way to see this implementation is that this is like e.g. `char` is defined in `libunicode` and can only have an inherent implementation in that crate (this is consistent with how coherence works), with the caveat that `char` is actually available everywhere because is part of the language/compiler.

@alexcrichton 

I respectfully disagree.

> I'm starting to somewhat have second thoughts about this from a compiler implementation perspective. From an API standpoint I think this change is fine largely because it doesn't really change much. Overall, however, this seems like it's all a bit of a hack.

I think it is quite valuable from an API perspective, but more on that below.

> We're basically bending the language to our whim to enable this sort of functionality because we control the compiler, but from the perspective of some other hypothetical compiler implementor this becomes quite a pain. We're adding all these special cases for these very implementation-specific set of `impl` blocks for each primitive. Put another way, we've found the language inadequate for our desires so we're getting around that with some slight of hand that doesn't come up too much but likely will at some point.

I think this is overstated in several ways.

While we've moved many things into the libraries, the problem here is precisely to do with _primitive types_, which are specifically types that cannot be defined in the language itself and must be taken as given. In particular, I see adding inherent impls for these types as _bringing them up to parity_ with other library types; currently, we cannot follow standard conventions or API design for these special types! That is, this isn't "bending the language to our whim", it's making sure that primitive types and user-defined types work in more similar ways.

> I think the biggest pain points for me when reading this are:
> - Such a huge number of lang items were added.

That by itself doesn't seem like a problem to me. The point here is to uniformly add the ability to give inherent methods for primitive types, and there are many primitive types.

> - Multiple inherent implementations on primitives is allowed

I can see how this aspect feels a bit more hacky/implementation-specific. It's basically tied to the facade setup. But see below.

> The lang item problem can probably be considered an implementation detail of the compiler, but allowing multiple inherent implementations makes me feel like something has gone awry somewhere. We don't have the luxury of always being able to bend the language so API design is a little easier, and I felt that the previous trait-per-primitive-in-the-prelude solution was quite adequate: it worked out well in terms of documentation, functionality, extensibility, and it was also consistent with the rest of the language.  

It's a little difficult to tease apart the various concerns here. It seems like you're making a slippery slope kind of argument that this is "bending the language" but as I argued above, at least the idea of having inherent impls for primitive types it just making the language more internally consistent between primitive and user-defined types.

As to the question of having multiple inherent impls, that is indeed one sense in which this PR goes beyond what the language provides elsewhere. However, I consider this, like all other aspects of the facade, a hidden and changeable implementation detail. The commitment here is just to have _some_ inherent methods visible in `std`, but the precise way that is broken down is up for grabs. (I personally don't mind the inherent split, but we could certainly discuss changing it; however, I don't think it should block this PR since it can be tweaked later.)

As to the status quo: I personally disagree that it worked out quite well. In particular, it is already difficult for newcomers to Rust to understand how Deref and dispatch work together to make methods show up for things like `Vec`, but then the fact that the relevant methods were defined on an extension trait add that much more of a barrier. In addition, for the numeric types, the traits are routinely misunderstood as being intended for full-blown generic programming over numerics, and they aren't suited for that. (That latter could be addressed by introducing separate extension traits for each type.)

I think that when it comes to the primitive types of the language, we should make things as simple and transparent as possible. People have to learn a lot of things when they come to Rust, and not having inherent methods on our basic types is both inconsistent with other types and adds yet another indirection for something very basic.

@eddyb 

> Does that seem like less of a hack to you?

For me personally I don't think so. It looks like you're introducing a new type `i32` which is an `enum` (not the primitive) in that statement, which feels odd to me. Additionally, it doesn't remove the need for extension traits due to the facade which to me reduces its utility. I haven't spent a great deal of time digesting it, though, so I may be missing pieces here and there.

---

@japaric 

> Just to clarify, only a single inherent implementation, the one marked with the lang item, is permitted per primitive

Oh I apologize, I have gotten the wrong impression! I seem to remember in a previous incarnation there was a `core_char` and `unicode_char` impl block, but I see now that the traits remain in libcore and the inherent impls only show up later.

---

@aturon 

> That is, this isn't "bending the language to our whim", it's making sure that primitive types and user-defined types work in more similar ways.

To me this isn't necessarily a good thing, though. To me it's unclear whether the primitive types should behave the same as user-defined types because they really are special (compiler-defined). To me there's kinda understanding concerns here:
1. Understanding how methods are available on primitives
2. Understanding what methods are available on primitives

Today we excel at 1 for primitives because everyone puts methods on them the same way, through traits. I do agree though that 2 is lacking today because one has to look at trait implementations for methods.

This PR, however, inverts the situation in my mind. Point 2 we start to excel at because the documentation for primitives looks the same as all other types (plus you don't have to import anything to get the methods). Point 1, however, becomes a little more confusing. For example someone may have the question "wait, can't inherent methods only be defined on types defined in a crate?".

I think I'm leaning towards importance on point 1 whereas you prefer point 2, but I may be getting persuaded as well.

> > Multiple inherent implementations on primitives is allowed
> 
> I can see how this aspect feels a bit more hacky/implementation-specific. It's basically tied to the facade setup. 

Ah this point is actually moot due to my misunderstanding of the implementation (cleared up [by @japaric](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/23104#issuecomment-78538419)).

> It seems like you're making a slippery slope kind of argument that this is "bending the language"

Being my usual self, I do think this is one of my concerns :). I somewhat fear that we still consider having the ability to do so this late in the game, eventually we won't have this "escape hatch". That being said I also understand the point that there is no better time to make this change than now.

> As to the question of having multiple inherent impls

Although my understanding was off, I just wanted to make sure that a concern brought up by @eddyb on IRC was listed here. In this PR libcore does not contain an inherent impl for `str`, it is instead in libcollections. This goes against the "inherent implementations are only allowed in the defining crate" and could in theory have unintended consequences on coherence at some point. For now, though, I do think that we're somewhat safe where we can consider the "defining crate" as the standard library and worry about the `no_std` case later.

> As to the status quo: I personally disagree that it worked out quite well ... but then the fact that the relevant methods were defined on an extension trait add that much more of a barrier

I'm a little surprised that the methods are hard to discover, the [documentation page for `str`](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html), for example, has all of the methods listed at the bottom b/c trait impls are shown. I also feel like this concern is separable from whether we use traits or inherent methods because this can arguably all be fixed via rustdoc.

> In addition, for the numeric types, the traits are routinely misunderstood as being intended for full-blown generic programming over numerics, and they aren't suited for that.

This is a good point that I had forgotten!

> People have to learn a lot of things when they come to Rust, and not having inherent methods on our basic types is both inconsistent with other types and adds yet another indirection for something very basic.

I'm not sure I totally agree with this concern, it seems objective to me. I believe that for something like `str` that a newcomer doesn't really care whether the `contains` method is inherent or imported via a trait. To me it seems like the pain point is the numeric traits which, as you mentioned, could be solved with a trait-per-primitive.

---

All in all I'm not quite sure how I still feel about this change. My objection of multiple inherent impl blocks motivated me to write my comment, but that was a misunderstanding so I'm not sure that there is sufficient motivation to push back on this. I think it's basically the same in my mind to have either inherent methods or a trait-per-primitive _from the std perspective_.

Good discussion. Some thoughts from my side :) I tried to quote and respond directly to people but found it hard to confine what I wanted to say to that format, so I'll just ramble a bit instead.

First off, while lang items are not standardized, if were going to produce a full reference version of the language, we would have to standardize at least some of them. `UnsafeCell`, `PhantomData`, the `Copy` trait, etc, are all types that bend the normal rules. I'm not sure why it should be so problematic to have an impl that bends the normal rules (unless the _way_ that it bends them is a problem).

Due to these lang items, the rust language basically already requires that all Rust crates can be arrange into a tree with a single root, the "standard library" (at present, this is always libstd, but I imagine it can be changed over time). Furthermore, it seems natural to consider the primitive types to be "local" to this root crate. In that case, the fact that the root crate can define inherent impls on the primitive types makes total sense and is not inconsistent with our existing system. So it shouldn't be surprising to users that they can't make inherent methods on `i32` any more than they can make inherent methods on `Vec` or `Option`.

This is somewhat complicated by the existence of the facade -- when you zoom into the root crate, it turns out to have some structure to it (I really want to make some metaphor about quarks and atoms, but anyway). But I feel like this is ultimately a kind of minor concern. For the vast majority of Rust programs, and all stable Rust programs, libstd is the root crate and is indivisible.

In the future, I imagine there will be some alternative standard libraries. They will all use libcore; but if we adopt this approach, it seems likely that they will have the responsibility / option of defining the methods on primitive types as well. I guess I'd be happier if all of the primitive methods could be confined to libcore, because then the root crate analogy is airtight, but ultimately I feel... more-or-less ok with saying that we will eventually stabilize the mechanisms you need to define your own "root crate" like "libstd", and that libcore and the other components of the facade are kind of pseudo-crates that you can reuse for this purpose. 

Does that make sense to anyone else?

@nikomatsakis 

> Furthermore, it seems natural to consider the primitive types to be "local" to this root crate.

I was talking about this with @aturon, but I think this may be a key point that I disagree on. I view the primitives as not having a defining crate because they're defined in the language itself. Emulating a "defining crate" (facade present or not) seems out of place to me. I think my motivation for this thinking is that `i32` is available to _all rust programs in existence_, not just those that link to libstd (or even libcore). Someone using libstd2 can have an `i32` which interoperates with libstd's `i32` (morally speaking, duplicate lang items would probably hinder this for other reasons).

> In that case, the fact that the root crate can define inherent impls on the primitive types makes total sense and is not inconsistent with our existing system.

Given the assumption that libstd is "defining primitives", I totally agree with this and the conclusions that follow. I just disagree on the premise :)

> But I feel like this is ultimately a kind of minor concern. For the vast majority of Rust programs, and all stable Rust programs, libstd is the root crate and is indivisible.

Depending on the route we're taking, the facade has differing degrees of how much it factors in I think. I believe that the current implementation by @japaric definition makes it so the facade doesn't matter much (as you pointed out). A strategy like @eddyb's, however, would be greatly affected by the facade.

I also do want to at least consider a possible future where libcore is `#[stable]` and part of the main distribution. I would personally find it a little jarring (not the end of the world though of course) to find the behavior different between std crates and `no_std` crates (e.g. what this PR does).

Although I do agree that the facade and/or non-libstd use cases shouldn't play a huge part in the decision for now, just a factor to consider!

---

As an aside, thanks for taking time to write up responses @nikomatsakis and @aturon!
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23245) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

Since lang items are not a stable interface (just yet), this strategy should be able to work in combination with "rooting" the named primitives types in libcore.
We are left then with special-cased orphan impls, which side-step de-coherence by using the pre-existing language item mechanism ("there can be only one") - not the end of the world, I guess.

Interestingly enough, only `char` and `str` need an `impl` outside of libcore - maybe they don't belong?
We have byte string literals, so panicking could use that.
What else would be broken, if we ignore third-party code which uses only libcore?

> Interestingly enough, only char and str need an impl outside of libcore - maybe they don't belong?

I believe slices, f32 and f64 also need external impls (allocation + math functions).
@alexcrichton ahhh I blame github for hiding some of the larger file diffs. I am still curious about `char` and `str` though.

(Note, it seems that in principle there are no longer _strong_ objections to this PR, and I personally still think this is very worthwhile for clarifying the numerics situation and making things friendlier for newcomers. @japaric, after you adjust the gaps you just realized the PR has, maybe @nikomatsakis can give a final review?)

Rebased and `make check-stage1`ed. This is what the last three commit do (from oldest to newest):
- Address @alexcrichton comment about the Makefile
- Move `impl f{32,64}` to libstd
- Address @nikomatsakis comment about not duplicating the definition of `to_vec`, `into_vec`, etc functions, and better document the hacks required to run the libcollections' unit tests.

This ready for the final review (@nikomatsakis?). The preview docs (see top comment) should get updated in half an hour or so.

Something that we should do right after merging this is unifying `impl f{32,64}` with a macro to keep the docs and the implementations synchronized, and also make a snapshot.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23333) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@nikomatsakis 

> It seems like what you are saying, basically, is that it would be nice if there could be alternatives to libstd that lived in (say) cargo and which can be combined with libstd code.

I'd also go a little bit more general as well to say that crates which only depend on core interact with these methods differently than crates that depend on the standard library. This is just a "purity" argument in a sense though, ergonomically there's no downside either way.

> But we might also consider whether we want to integrate inherent methods into the trait system somehow so that it is possible to have multiple sets of "inherent" methods (and perhaps one must somehow pick-and-choose which one to use?). Variations on this theme have been requested over time.

This is a very good point! One I had not considered much. It does indicate to me that my perceived "impurity" here may not actually be so impure in the long run (in which case I'm running out of arguments!).

> I guess the important thing is that it doesn't seem like we're fundamentally ruling out the possibility of having a standardized libcore if we go this route. We are committing however to either having libstd get the benefit of inherent methods on scalar types while others don't, or else finding a way to bridge this gap in the future so that multiple sets of inherent methods can co-exist (which is probably going to wind up being somewhat similar to the trait scheme we have now).

I agree with this, and I've come around to being ok with this :)
r+ from me
@bors: r=nikomatsakis b65ebc4
:hourglass: Testing commit b65ebc4 with merge e466109...

:sunny: Test successful - [auto-linux-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-nopt-t/builds/4086), [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/4090), [auto-linux-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-nopt-t/builds/4072), [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/4080), [auto-linux-64-x-android-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-x-android-t/builds/4053), [auto-mac-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-32-opt/builds/4106), [auto-mac-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-nopt-t/builds/4106), [auto-mac-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-opt/builds/4093), [auto-win-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-32-nopt-t/builds/3766), [auto-win-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-32-opt/builds/3752), [auto-win-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-64-nopt-t/builds/2583), [auto-win-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-64-opt/builds/2590)
Are any crate now allowed to have inherent implementations for primitive types? If not, what is the rule that allows e.g. libunicode to do it?
@SimonSapin The rule is effectively: a single crate within the `std` facade can define the implementation.

@SimonSapin To expand on @aturon's answer: it's done with `#[lang=...]` on the impls themselves.
Any lang item can be defined at most once in a crate hierarchy, and libstd (and all of its constituents, behind the facade) "happens" to have _all_ the lang items taken for itself.

That means _no_ crate using libstd can add methods to any of the primitives supporting this mechanism.
However, crates depending on _only_ libcore can implement any of the lang items that are not in libcore (e.g. the ones for `char` and `str`).
That sounds reasonable. Thanks for the explanation!
